content.summary: Kilian Valkhof explains how many functions that were previously written in JavaScript can now be solved with HTML and CSS. He follows the Rule of Least Power, using the least powerful technology that can do the job.
highlights: Modern HTML & CSS features that replace JavaScript

features.title: Custom Switches
features.description: The <input type="checkbox"> can be styled as a switch with appearance: none; and additional CSS.

features.title: Input Color
features.description: Color pickers are now standard with <input type="color">, no extra JavaScript needed.

features.title: Smooth Scrolling
features.description: With scroll-behavior: smooth; in CSS, anchor links can scroll smoothly without JS.

features.title: Accordion
features.description: The <details> and <summary> elements create an interactive expandable menu without JavaScript.

features.title: Dialog Element
features.description: <dialog> replaces JavaScript alerts and provides full control over modal windows.

features.title: Parent Selector :has()
features.description: CSS can now check if an element contains another, making styling more flexible.

features.title: Scroll-Driven Animations
features.description: Heavy JavaScript scroll animations can now be done more efficiently with pure CSS.

content.conclusion: Valkhof emphasizes that HTML and CSS are becoming increasingly powerful, reducing dependency on JavaScript and making websites faster and more robust.

title: Pay the Web Forward with web monetization
speaker: Peter-Paul Koch

content.summary: Peter-Paul Koch discusses the necessity of paid websites and alternatives to advertising. He argues that not everything needs to be free and that web services deserve fair funding methods, such as subscriptions, pay-per-visit, or payment based on time spent.

items.title: Wallets
items.description: Digital wallets linked to bank accounts.

items.title: Browser Extensions
items.description: Acting as intermediaries to execute payments.

items.title: Spending Rate
items.description: Users determine how much they want to pay.

items.title: Web Monetization Agent
items.description: Manages payments, processes transactions, and sends events to developers.

items.title: Offline tracking
items.description: Local storage (cookies/localStorage) can track how long a user visits a site, allowing payment processing later.

content.challenges: Current challenges include regional regulations (e.g., US vs. EU) and the lack of a standardized wallet. Once these are resolved, web monetization can work globally.
content.conclusion: Koch emphasizes that a fair and sustainable payment system is necessary for the future of the web, without dependence on advertising.

content.summary: Cassie Evans explores the advanced capabilities of GSAP, a powerful JavaScript animation library. She emphasizes that GSAP is more than just tweening, offering a comprehensive toolkit for creating complex and precise animations without sacrificing performance.

features.title: Timelines
features.description: For creating structured, complex animation sequences

features.title: GSAP Utils
features.description: Functions like random(), mapRange(), and wrap() for dynamic animations

features.title: Modifiers
features.description: For real-time adjustment of variables in animations

features.title: Easing
features.description: Critical for smooth movements (with an Ease Visualizer available on the GSAP site)

features.title: OnMouse and Drag Events
features.description: Built-in event handling for interactive animations

features.title: MotionPath Helper
features.description: For visual editing of animation paths directly in the browser

content.conclusion: GSAP provides a flexible toolbox that allows users to build more complex and precise animations without losing performance benefits.

content.summary: Nils Binder is a German frontend designer at 9elements with expertise in communication design, product development, and web development. His focus is on the interplay between mathematics and design, typography, and CSS structures.

sections.title: Professional Background
sections.description: Nils began his career working in Photoshop but has now fully transitioned to Figma due to its code-based features, such as drop shadows and auto-layout (comparable to display: flex in CSS).

sections.title: Design Philosophy
sections.description: In his work, he experiments with various CSS solutions, seeking a balance between clarity and efficiency. He draws inspiration from "A Dao of Web Design" by Jon Allsopp.

sections.title: Technical Exploration
sections.description: Nils experiments with flexible units, ranging from px and em to svw and container queries. He often finds the proper size and display of wrapper elements challenging.

sections.title: Future Direction
sections.description: Although he hasn't worked with mobile-first design commercially, he's open to experimenting with it. Currently, his clients don't prioritize mobile designs, but he's eager to explore beyond standard stacked layouts in future projects.

content.summary: Julia Miocene is a talented UX Engineer at GitLab, working on the UX Paper Cuts team. She is also a Google Developer Expert, Women Techmakers Ambassador, YouTuber, and a renowned artist in the world of Pure CSS Art, especially known for her cartoony style creations.

sections.title: CSS Wizardry
sections.description: Julia is a true wizard with CSS, often pushing the boundaries of what's possible by using unconventional techniques—like crafting triangles using borders or experimenting with complex shapes and animations entirely in CSS. Her work frequently appears on platforms like CodePen, where she shares creative and technically impressive results.

sections.title: Reflection Process
sections.description: What sets Julia apart is not just her creativity but also her rigorous reflection and iteration process. She's not afraid to experiment, but she carefully evaluates her work afterwards, identifying techniques that might lead to performance issues and consciously choosing not to reuse them.

sections.title: Animation Philosophy
sections.description: Julia emphasizes the importance of holistic motion design. Instead of animating components in isolation, she considers the entire interface, ensuring all animations work together cohesively. She brings in principles from the real world—like foreground objects moving faster than those in the background—to make animations feel more natural.

sections.title: Practical Approach
sections.description: She advises building animated objects by first identifying their structural elements: what belongs together, what needs to be a parent-child relationship, and mirroring that in the HTML. This logical foundation makes animating more intuitive and manageable. A fun fact: Julia has even discovered that CSS can be used inside emails, opening up creative possibilities in unexpected places.

content.summary: Rosa Schuurmans, an ex-CMD student involved with the Repair Café movement, gave an inspiring lecture about circuit bending — the creative reuse and hacking of old electronic devices to create new, unexpected functions and sounds.

sections.title: Creative Experimentation
sections.description: Rosa demonstrated how important it is to experiment and think outside the box. She provided examples of how you can create unique interactive objects using simple tools like a soldering iron, old toy instruments, or discarded electronics.

sections.title: Technological Independence
sections.description: An important theme in her talk was technological independence. Rosa encouraged us to think platform-agnostically: ensure your creations aren't dependent on big tech companies or closed systems. By breaking open devices and reshaping them, you take back control over technology and stimulate your own creativity and technical insight.

sections.title: Repair Café Philosophy
sections.description: She emphasized the importance of the Repair Café philosophy: don't immediately throw something away when it breaks, but see if you can repair it or transform it into something new. This mentality contributes to sustainability and innovation.

sections.title: Call to Action
sections.description: Finally, the presentation was above all a call to action: "Pick up the soldering iron and start hacking!" Dare to tinker, learn by doing, and have fun with the unexpected.

title: Declarative vs Imperative: Two Mindsets for Building the Web
speaker: Jeremy Keith

content.summary: In 'Declarative Design', Jeremy Keith explores the philosophical and practical differences between declarative and imperative programming—two fundamental approaches to solving problems in code.

sections.title: Two Programming Paradigms
sections.description: The imperative style is like reading sheet music or following a recipe: you describe step by step how something should happen. This is common in languages like JavaScript, where one wrong step can stop the entire process. It gives developers explicit control, but also a higher chance of error. The declarative style is more like jamming with a band—you focus on the desired outcome, and the system figures out how to make it happen.

sections.title: Web Evolution
sections.description: These mindsets shaped how the World Wide Web evolved: HTML was the starting point—a declarative language that defines structure. CSS followed—a declarative way to suggest styles. JavaScript then introduced imperative control—telling the browser exactly what to do and when.

sections.title: CSS Power
sections.description: Although CSS is declarative, it still offers significant control through advanced tools like min(), max(), clamp(), fit-content, and calc(). So, declarative doesn't mean 'less power'—just a different kind of power.

sections.title: Context Matters
sections.description: Whether declarative is 'better' than imperative depends entirely on the context. Imperative systems offer more structure and control, which can be helpful in tightly managed environments. Declarative systems offer flexibility and abstraction, often leading to simpler and more maintainable code.

resources: Every Layout – deep dives into layout patterns using declarative principles
Layout Land on YouTube – great video tutorials on CSS and layout design
Build Excellent Websites – a philosophy-first approach to building for the web

content.summary: Jeremy Keith is an Irish web developer and author known for his sharp insights into the evolution of the web. He speaks at conferences worldwide about web development and has written influential books such as 'DOM Scripting' (2005), 'Bulletproof Ajax', and 'HTML5 for Web Designers'. Jeremy has a great passion for the history of the web and enjoys seeing how HTML, CSS, and JavaScript have evolved over the years.

sections.title: Vision on Web Development
sections.description: According to Jeremy, web development is most powerful when approached in three steps: 1) What is the core functionality? 2) What is the simplest technology to achieve that? 3) Let's enhance it! (Progressive enhancement). The first two steps ensure broad accessibility (including people with slower connections or more limited devices), while step three provides room to add extra functionality for users with modern browsers.

sections.title: Design Principles
sections.description: Jeremy adheres to principles like the Robustness Principle (Postel's Law): 'Be conservative in what you send, be liberal in what you accept.' HTML and CSS follow this thinking: even if you make a mistake, the browser tries to display the content as best as possible. He also follows the Rule of Least Power: Choose the least powerful language that can still perform a task, ensuring more stability, security, and reusability.

sections.title: Web Standards Evolution
sections.description: Jeremy often discusses how functionalities that were once exclusive to JavaScript are increasingly shifting to HTML and CSS. Think of form validation, animations, and interactive elements.

sections.title: Browser Storage Options
sections.description: He mentions various ways to store data in the browser: Cookies, localStorage, sessionStorage, IndexedDB, and Cache API (the most performant option).

content.summary: Niels Leenheer presented how to build a cash register system using web technology, focusing on Google's Project Fugu that extends web technology with powerful APIs to give web apps access to hardware like printers, scanners, and payment terminals.

sections.title: Project Fugu & Real-World Applications
sections.description: Project Fugu is a Google initiative that extends web technologies with powerful APIs, giving web apps access to hardware like printers, scanners, and payment terminals. Niels demonstrated this through Salon Hub, a hair salon appointment and cash register system built with web technologies, potentially also offering internships.

sections.title: Building Blocks
sections.description: These systems are built with Electron for desktop apps, Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) that also work on tablets like Android, and Project Fugu APIs that enable communication with peripherals.

sections.title: Receipt Printers
sections.description: These work via WebUSB (only in Chromium browsers). You need to communicate with the printer using ASCII commands, but ASCII is outdated—Unicode is now the standard. Every printer speaks a different 'language', requiring specific code per printer. Future solution: Use WebSerial or WebBluetooth → more reliable & universal.

sections.title: Peripheral Devices
sections.description: Customer displays communicate via ESC/POS (old protocol, boring but still widely used). WebSerial is a modern solution to control these. Barcode scanners behave like keyboards (typing numbers + enter) and support multiple types of barcodes including GTIN. QR codes work similarly to barcodes but often lead to URLs, which cash register systems typically ignore.

content.conclusion: The main lesson: building a cash register system with web technology is possible thanks to modern Web APIs (Project Fugu). It's technically challenging, but thanks to Niels' open source work, you don't have to reinvent the wheel. Thanks to nerds like Niels, we'll soon be able to build cash registers in the browser.

title: IDEA11Y Meetup — Inclusive Design & Accessibility in Practice
speaker: Erik Kroes, Anastasia, Nienke de Keijzer

content.summary: As part of the CN Donderdagen series and the Weekly Nerd program, this special English-language edition focused on accessibility (a11y) in digital design. The event featured multiple speakers sharing insights on implementing inclusive design principles and practical WCAG fixes.
content.introduction: The vision behind CN Donderdagen is to critically explore the role of design today — by hosting talks and inviting experts to help collectively question, reflect, and maybe even get closer to the one true answer. This event marked the first English-language talk in the series, opening the conversation to an international perspective on inclusive design.

speakers.name: Erik Kroes
speakers.title: Practical Fixes for Common WCAG Failures

topics.title: Keyboard Navigation
topics.details: "If you can't use a site without a mouse, you can't use it at all." Tab should take you to every interactive element. Shift + Tab goes backwards. Make sure you include a skip link to bypass repetitive navigation. Always define a clear focus state — users need to see where they are. Avoid using generic <div> elements as buttons unless they are properly labeled for screen readers.

topics.title: Contrast
topics.details: Even users with good eyesight struggle with poor contrast — especially in bright environments. Target contrast ratio: at least 3:1. Watch out for low-contrast placeholders, branding colors, and hover/active states. All major browsers now support contrast-checking tools.

topics.title: Alternatives
topics.details: Provide accessible alternatives for non-text content: Alt text for images, captions and transcripts for video and audio, meaningful labels and descriptions for assistive technologies.

topics.title: Sizing
topics.details: Design with flexibility. Let users adjust text and interface sizes without breaking the layout. Use relative units (like em, rem, %) instead of fixed pixels where possible.

speakers.name: Anastasia
speakers.title: Beyond WCAG: Broader Perspectives on Inclusion
speakers.details: Accessibility isn't just checkboxes — it's about understanding different abilities, contexts, and cultures. Ask: Who is left out when we design this way?

speakers.name: Nienke de Keijzer
speakers.title: Thinking Outside the Accessibility Box
speakers.details: Design systems with morphing needs in mind. Include neurodiversity, temporary impairments, and edge cases. Move from compliance → to compassion.

takeaways: Think declaratively: structure your HTML meaningfully before adding interactivity
Start simple: build a strong, accessible core — then enhance
Always test your work with keyboard navigation and screen reader tools
Accessibility isn't a blocker — it's a creative constraint
content.conclusion: Accessibility is not a bonus feature. It's the foundation of good digital design.

content.summary: Marieke de Hoop, oud-CMD-student, vertelt waarom digitale toegankelijkheid iedereen aangaat. Ze legt uit dat ongeveer 32% van de mensen in Nederland een permanente beperking heeft (5,5 miljoen mensen), maar dat ook tijdelijke of situationele beperkingen het gebruik van digitale tools kunnen bemoeilijken.

sections.title: Toegankelijkheid in cijfers
sections.description: Ongeveer 32% van de mensen in Nederland heeft een permanente beperking – dat zijn 5,5 miljoen mensen. Ook tijdelijke of situationele beperkingen, zoals een gebroken arm, migraine, fel zonlicht of overprikkeling, kunnen het gebruik van digitale tools moeilijk maken.

sections.title: Ontwerpen met empathie
sections.description: Toegankelijkheid draait om ontwerpen met empathie. Marieke benadrukt dat jouw eigen ervaringen met beperkingen meer diepgang kunnen geven aan je ontwerp. De toegankelijkheidsbranche is breed en richt zich op onderzoek, advies, trainingen, projectmanagement en het ontwikkelen van toegankelijke producten.

sections.title: Praktijkwerk en audits
sections.description: Zelf voert Marieke toegankelijkheidsaudits uit aan de hand van de WCAG-richtlijnen, waarbij onder andere gekeken wordt naar code, contrast en semantiek. Een voorbeeld is haar werk met ASR, waar het hele bedrijf wordt doorgelicht op digitale toegankelijkheid. Daarnaast geeft ze trainingen aan studenten en bedrijven om bewustwording te vergroten.

sections.title: European Accessibility Act
sections.description: De aankomende European Accessibility Act verplicht toegankelijkheid voor onder andere webshops, banken en telecombedrijven die consumenten bedienen. Er geldt een overgangsperiode van vijf jaar voor bestaande content. Kleine B2B-bedrijven vallen soms buiten de regeling, maar vrijstellingen zijn zeldzaam. Niet voldoen kan leiden tot boetes tot 20 miljoen euro of 10% van de omzet.

content.conclusion: Toegankelijkheid is geen bijzaak, maar essentieel voor iedereen die digitale producten ontwerpt of ontwikkelt.

content.summary: Tijdens het bezoek aan Q42 kregen we een rondleiding en een inspirerend praatje van Vasilis over waarom hij Q42 het allerbeste nerd bureau vindt. Volgens hem komt dat door hun unieke aanpak: toegankelijkheid staat hier al meer dan 12 jaar centraal, direct vanaf het begin van het ontwerp.

sections.title: Wat is Q42?
sections.description: Q42 maakt digitale producten die het leven van mensen leuker, slimmer en makkelijker maken. Met meer dan 100 medewerkers ('Q'ers') en vestigingen in Amsterdam, Den Haag (en in de toekomst ook Rotterdam), werken ze voor klanten zoals HEMA, Rijksmuseum, Philips Hue en Wie is de Mol? Daarnaast werken ze ook aan inhouse projecten, zoals VR- en AR-toepassingen en zelfs fysieke installaties.

sections.title: Het Q-DNA
sections.description: Het Q-DNA bestaat uit toegankelijkheid (zo vroeg mogelijk in het proces meenemen), strijden voor de gebruiker (bijvoorbeeld met de eigen gebruikerstestmethode RUN), innovatie (door te blijven spelen met nieuwe technologie), W00tcamp (interne hackathon) en Passiedag (elke twee weken werken aan eigen projecten op vrijdag). 'Als programmeurs beperken we onze gebruikers – daarom moeten we zorgen dat dit níét gebeurt.'

sections.title: Regelgeving
sections.description: De European Accessibility Act (EAA) verplicht digitale toegankelijkheid. WCAG-richtlijnen zijn essentieel voor gebruikers die niet goed kunnen zien, horen, bewegen of begrijpen.

sections.title: Medewerkers aan het woord
sections.description: Lars, oud-CMD'er, werkt inmiddels 2 jaar bij Q42. Zijn rol zit tussen design en development in, met een constante focus op de gebruiker.

projects.title: SenseMath
projects.description: Ontwikkeld met en voor kinderen met een visuele beperking (i.s.m. Visio). Zet wiskundige grafieken om in geluid via frequentiemodulatie en ook voelbare grafieken via swell paper. Verschillende geluiden geven hoogte en vorm van de grafiek aan. Koppeling met boeken: de app weet welke pagina je gebruikt. Belangrijk inzicht: jonge kinderen hebben minder details nodig in het ontwerp.

projects.title: Oculi Mundi
projects.description: Een digitale ervaring rond oude atlassen van een rijke familie. De klant wilde géén 'standaard site', maar een echte ervaring. De planeten hadden makkelijk met WebGL gemaakt kunnen worden, maar WebGL is beperkt toegankelijk. Daarom bewust gekozen voor HTML en CSS, met minimale inzet van WebGL. Toegankelijkheid stond voorop zonder visuele kracht te verliezen.

content.conclusion: Q42 combineert technische innovatie met menselijke waarden. Ze ontwerpen niet alleen mooie en slimme producten, maar zorgen er ook voor dat die werken voor iedereen met toegankelijkheid als vanzelfsprekend fundament.

title: Weekly Nerd bij iO Digital
speaker: Dave Bitter, Steve Jonk, Clarke Verdel

content.summary: Bij iO Digital kregen we een kijkje in de keuken van een zogenoemd blended agency, waar technologie, creativiteit en marketing samenkomen. Ze werken aan de volledige digitale experience: van branding tot aftercare, social media tot self service-platforms.

sections.title: Over iO Digital
sections.description: iO Digital is een blended agency waar technologie, creativiteit en marketing samenkomen. Ze werken voor klanten zoals PostNL, bol.com, Audi, Amnesty en de Efteling aan vraagstukken zoals: Hoe kunnen studenten slimmer samenwerken? (Acco), Real-time data van warehouse tot winkelvloer (Vans), Minder wachttijd in de Efteling, Responsible gokken bij de Nationale Loterij, en AI-project 'Laika 13': opvoeding van een tiener via social media (Zweden).

talks.speaker: Dave Bitter
talks.title: AI powered voice interfaces
talks.description: Dave liet zien hoe hij een oude webapplicatie (PresiParrot) nieuw leven inblies met AI. Met de Web Speech API (speech recognition & synthesis) en een lokaal AI-model maakt hij volledige spraakgestuurde communicatie mogelijk.
highlights: Prompt-engineering: ChatGPT instrueren om alleen via audio te communiceren
Tools als ElevenLabs voor betere spraaksynthese
Belangrijk punt: Wachten op een AI-reactie moet snel en vloeiend aanvoelen
talks.quote: Pak een oud project van jezelf en geef het een AI-upgrade!

talks.speaker: Steve Jonk
talks.title: Twitter Follow Bot
talks.description: Steve bouwde een Twitter (X) bot voor automatisch volgen en ontvolgen van accounts. Een 'grijs gebied'-project dat laat zien hoe ver je kunt gaan met open data.
details: Gebruikte tools als n8n (workflow automation), Puppeteer (scraping)
Scrapte followers via netwerkrequests omdat X ze niet meer toont in de frontend
Randomizers toegevoegd om bots te maskeren
Leerde hoe API-limieten, rate limits en anti-bot-mechanismen werken
talks.quote: Technisch kan er veel, maar ethisch en legaal moet je ook goed opletten.

talks.speaker: Clarke Verdel
talks.title: Testen als een echte gebruiker
talks.description: Clarke legde uit hoe bij iO componenten en flows automatisch getest worden, net zoals een echte gebruiker dat zou doen. Dit wordt onder andere toegepast bij Miele X, waar ze een platform voor 26 landen bouwen.
testStructure: Tools zoals Vitest en component-driven testing
talks.quote: Een goede developer weet hoe hij moet testen. Het kost tijd, het is niet altijd leuk, maar het maakt je code betrouwbaar.

takeaways: Superinteressante middag met sterke balans tussen tech en praktijkvoorbeelden
Veel geleerd over AI in de frontend, automatisering en teststrategieën
Inspiratie om oude projecten te revisiten met nieuwe technologie
iO Digital is een plek waar creativiteit en code écht samenkomen

content.summary: Niels Leenheer liet zien hoe je een kassasysteem bouwt met webtechnologie, gebruikmakend van Google's Project Fugu dat webtechnologie uitbreidt met krachtige API's voor toegang tot hardware zoals printers, scanners en pinapparaten.

sections.title: Wat is Project Fugu?
sections.description: Een initiatief van Google dat webtechnologie uitbreidt met krachtige API's, zodat webapps toegang krijgen tot hardware zoals printers, scanners en pinapparaten.

sections.title: Een kassa met webtechnologie
sections.description: Voorbeeld: Salon Hub - een kappersafspraak- en kassasysteem gebaseerd op webtech (mogelijk ook een stageplek). Gebouwd met Electron voor desktop-apps, Progressive Web Apps (PWA's) die ook werken op tablets zoals Android, en Project Fugu API's die communicatie met randapparatuur mogelijk maken.

hardware.title: Bonprinter
hardware.description: Werkt via WebUSB (alleen in Chromium browsers). Je moet 'praten' met de printer via ASCII-commando's, maar ASCII is verouderd → Unicode is nu de standaard. Elke printer spreekt een andere 'taal', dus je schrijft specifieke code per printer. Gebruik van JS-libraries is vaak complex en frustrerend.
hardware.futuresolution: Gebruik WebSerial of WebBluetooth → betrouwbaarder & universeel

hardware.title: Klantschermen
hardware.description: Communiceren via ESC/POS (oud protocol, saai maar nog veelgebruikt). WebSerial is een moderne oplossing om dit aan te sturen.

hardware.title: Barcode Scanner
hardware.description: Gedraagt zich als een toetsenbord (typt nummers + enter). Meerdere soorten barcodes → o.a. GTIN (Global Trade Item Number).
solutions: Webcam-module die barcodes op canvas uitleest met een worker

hardware.title: QR Codes
hardware.description: Werken hetzelfde als barcodes, maar leiden vaak naar URL's. Kassasystemen negeren dit meestal (geen probleem).

content.conclusion: Het bouwen van een kassasysteem met webtechnologie is mogelijk dankzij moderne Web API's (Project Fugu). Het is technisch uitdagend, maar dankzij open source werk van Niels hoef je het wiel niet opnieuw uit te vinden. Dankzij nerds zoals Niels kunnen we straks kassa's bouwen in de browser.
